Health Education and Promotion (Question No. 2873) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 7 April 1998: NA (1) What health education and health promotion programs does his Department conduct for veterans and war widows. (2) What (a) program and (b) running costs were allocated to the activities referred to in part (1) in (i) 1995-96, (ii) 1996-97 and (iii) 1997-98. (3) Through which appropriation item are the activities funded. (4) What is the forward estimate for expenditure on the activities in (a) 1998-99 and (b) 1999-2000. Mr Bruce Scott-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) My Department has two comprehensive programs in place to address preventive health issues: the preventive health program for the veteran community as a whole and the healthy lifestyles courses conducted by the Vietnam Veterans Counselling Service (VVCS) for Vietnam and younger veterans. The preventive health program has as its cornerstone the Better Living Plan for the Veteran Community which is a strategic plan outlining my Department's approach to preventive health until the year 2000. The individual elements of the preventive health program include: a major health promotion grants program which provides funding for substantial programs which address the primary health needs of the veteran community; healthy lifestyle encouragement grants program which supports smaller health promotion activities; a dementia program which provides a range of training and materials on the management of dementia to assist carers, providers and those diagnosed with dementia; a prostate health awareness program, including a book and video to inform the veteran community and health providers on prostate health issues; Programs the Never Too Late! sport and recreation program in conjunction with the Australian SP0l1S Commission, to provide quality opportunities for veterans to participate in sport and recreatiqn modified to meet their particular needs; an educationlinfonnation program for health providers through bi-annual publication of the Veterans' Health magazine which raises awareness in health providers of the major health issues affecting the veteran community. Veterans' Health Week in October each year is the avenue to showcase to the veteran community those programs which have been successful and also the opportunity to highlight to the veteran community the benefits of a healthy lifestyle. The healthy lifestyles programs conducted by the VVCS address: coping skills and lifestyle management strategies during week-long residential programs in each state; physical health and fitness through Heartsafe programs conducted in conjunction with MBF and developed in consultation with the National Heart Foundation; weight management through Gutbusters programs; and coping skills for partners and children of veterans through psycho-educational groups for women and children. Additionally, in recognising the importance of appropriate medication use, my Department has developed the MediWise program. This program is designed to assist veterans and war widows by encouraging them to playa more active role in the safe use of their medications. Employment Services Regulatory Authority: Statistics (Question No. 2886) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 8 April 1998: (1) Did the Employment Services Regulatory Authority maintain statistics of breaches by job agencies concerning welfare clients; if so, will the statistics continue to be maintained; if not, why not; if so, (a) who will maintain the statistics, (b) will the (i) number of (ii) reasons for, and (iii) types of breaches concerning welfare clients by each job agency involved in the Jobs Network be include; and (c) will the statistics be publicly available, if not, why not. Dr Kemp-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Under the Social Security Act 1991 and Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 it is the responsibility of Centrelink to decide if a job seeker should be breached. The role of Contracted Case Managers in the breaching of clients was to identify activity test breaches and recommend breach action to Centrelink. I am advised that the Employment Services Rcgulatory Authority did not maintain any statistics on breach activity by Contracted Case Managers. (a) Job Network Members have a contractual obligation to notify Centrelink of any possible breach by a job seeker of their obligations relating to allowanccs payable under the Social Security Act 1991 and Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973. The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs (DEETY A) monitors, and will maintain statistics on, Job Network members' compliance with this obligation as part of the ongoing performance monitoring. (b) Information collected by DEETYA will include the i) number, ii) reasons for and iii) type of possible breaches notified by each Job Network Member. (c) Aggregated data on breaches will be publicly available as part of the evaluation of the Job Network. However statistics on possible breach notification by individual Job Network members will not be made publicly available. Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme (Question No. 2945) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 12 May 1998: (1) Further to his media announcement of 14 April 1998 about the Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme for 1997-98, (a) what were the skills of each migrant granted a visa, (b) where were they employed by (i) State, (ii) Australian Bureau of Statistics Region and (iii) local government area and (c) which company employed each migrant. (2) Are employers who participate in the scheme required to show that a resident of Australia with the required skills cannot be recruited. (3) Is an employer who is granted permission to bring a skilled migrant into Australia required to train an unemployed Australian to fill the job in future. (4) Does the Government examine a sponsoring company's historical commitment to training A - lstralians before approving the bringing in of a skilled migrant. Lettable Unexpired tenn of Space m 2 lease 800 1 year, 1 month 650 4 year, 10 month 709 9 month 477 1 month 653 1 year, 0 month (5) Are skilled migrants granted short-term visas when the requirement for their skills may be for a short duration. (6) Are all the skilled migrants covered by the scheme in (a) 1997-98 and (b) the eight months to February 1998 still employed by the sponsoring company. (7) Is there a penalty on either the skilled migrant or the sponsoring company if the former is not employed by the latter (a) one week, (b) two weeks, (c) one month, (d) two months, (e) six months, (f) twelve months or (g) two years after arrival in Australia. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (I) (a) to (c) The 14 April 1998 media release referred to 314 visas granted under the Regional Sponsored Migration Scheme (RSMS) in the eight months to the end of February 1998. This figure comprised of 10 1 principal applicants with the remaining number being accompanying family members. Details of the principal applicant's skills, location and employer are set out in the table below. (2) The RSMS is reliant on approved regional bodies to certify a range of matters including that the nominated position is a genuine full-time vacancy and that it cannot be filled from the local labour market. This process requires that employers demonstrate that they are unable to fill the vacancy. (3) There is no legislative requirement for participating employers to train unemployed Australians. It is expected that employment opportunities will be generated in regional and rural Australia as a result of RSMS sponsorship. The skilled worker is often not only essential to expanding business but in maintaining the viability of an existing business. (4) The majority of sponsoring employers demonstrate that they have been unable to fill the skilled vacancy despite sustained and often prolonged recruitment and training efforts. While employers prefer to recruit and train locally, the unique requirements and location of many positions have resulted in recruitment and training difficulties. (5) Employers under the RSMS are seeking to fill permanent long-term vacancies. Employment National: Remuneration Packages (Question No. 2972) Mr Martin Ferguson asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 13 May 1998: (1) What (a) is the period of the contract for, and (b) are the details of the remuneration package of, the managing director of Employment National. (2) How does the contract compare with that for the Secretary of his Department. (3) What is the period of appointment of the Board of Employment National. (4) Who appoints members of the Board. (5) What types of fees or other allowances, including travelling allowances, are paid to Board members. Dr Kemp-The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows: (1) Details of the remuneration packages of Employment National executives will be reported in the company's Annual Report in accordance with normal reporting practice. However, for your information, a similar question was asked at the Senate Legislation Committee 1997-98 Additional Estimates Supplementary Hearing, Question on Notice 859. This answer, which is reproduced below, provides details of the remuneration packages for the managing director, Company Secretary and Legal Counsel, General Manager, Operations and other senior executives within the organisation, as follows: No of Positions 14 3 1 (2) The salary for each Agency Head is determined by the Remuneration Tribunal and is promulgated annually in its Reports and Decisions publication. The current rate determined for the Secretary of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs is $142,130 per annum. Agency Heads are also entitled to a private plated vehicle for a nominal fee and suitable free parking arrangements. Employer-sponsored superannuation and assistance with telephone costs are standard entitlements, while spouse-accompanied travel domestically and overseas may be approved by the relevant Minister. Name Position MrDon Swan Chairman  Mr Greg Harvey Director Dr Denise Fleming Director Mr Harvey Parker Director Mr Andrew Kirk Director (4) In accordance with the company's Articles of Association and the Governance Arrangements for Commonwealth Government Business Enterprises the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs acting jointly with the Minister for Finance and Administration may appoint a person to be a director of the company, either to fill a vacancy (whether casual or otherwise) or in addition to existing directors. (5) The remuneration of directors is set in accordance with any applicable determination of the Remuneration Tribunal under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973. The Remuneration Tribunal in Determination Number 1 of 25 March 1997 determined remuneration arrangements as follows for Employment National directors: Part-time Chairman Fee: $60,000 per annum Travelling Allowance: Capital:$320 per night; Other $165 per night Part-time Director Fee: $25,000 per annum Travelling Allowance: Capital:$320 per night; Other $165 per night The managing director is paid such remuneration as the directors determine from time to time in accordance with any applicable determination of the Remuneration Tribunal under the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973. Agency Heads have the option of being appointed in accordance with the provisions contained in section 37 of the Public Service Act 1922. These provisions allow, inter alia, for the payment of Loss of Tenure Allowance. This allowance amounts to an additional 20 per cent of annual salary each year and is paid on a fortnightly basis in conjunction with the standard salary payment. (3) The period of appointment of Board members has been staggered to ensure a continuation of corporate knowledge within the Board of Employment National. The terms for current Board members are as follows: Term 3 years for term not exceeding five years 3 years 3 years 2 years 2 years Work Visas (Question No. 3009) Mr Laurie Ferguson asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 27 May 1998: (1) Did analysis by the Committee of Inquiry into the Temporary Entry of Business People and Highly Skilled Specialists indicate the potential for temporary skills transfer through possible offshore sponsorship by multinational corporations. (2) Has there been a pronounced growth in the issue of onshore category 457 visas; if so, why. (3) What statistical material does his Department collate concerning category 457 visas. (4) How many visitors to Australia had work rights at 30 April 1998. (5) How many employers were (a) granted rights and (b) rejected as category 457 sponsors (i) in 1997 and (ii) between 1 January and 30 April 1998. (6) What were the predominant industry categories associated with seeking onshore changes to 457 long stay status. Mr Ruddock-The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows: (1) In its report presented to the Government in August 1995, the Committee of Inquiry into the Temporary Entry into the Temporary Entry of Business People and Highly Skilled Specialists considered that the primary principle governing the temporary entry of key business personnel should be benefit to Australia. The benefits envisaged by the Committee included the introduction of new or improved technology or business skills in Australia. The Committee recommended streamlined processing for key business personnel for both companies operating in Australia and reputable overseas companies seeking to establish a business presence or fulfil a contract in Australia. Overseas company sponsorships must also be of benefit to Australia. (2) It is estimated that there will be 18,350 subclass 457 visas granted onshore in 1997/98, compared to 14,150 visas granted in 1996/97. The visa grant figures include approximately 40 per cent dependents. The increase in onshore visa grants is consistent with government expectations. The components of this growth include: - an underlying increase in business reliance on key personnel associated with growth in Australia's economy and international trade, and the need for business to be more internationally competitive; - greater reliance of business on the use of skilled temporary residents rather than the more traditional and less streamlined sponsorship of permanent residents; - establishment of specialised Business Units in Australia to better respond to business realities and the time-critical needs of business; and - an increased initial use of the business visitor visa (subclass 456) and a consequential increase in subsequent business long-stay visa (subclass 457) applications onshore. NA Agriculture, Forestry and Fishing Mining Manufacturing Electricity, Gas and Water Supply Construction Wholesale Trade Retail Trade Accommodation, Cafes and Restaurants Transport and Storage Communication Services (3) The Department routinely collects a broad range of visa and sponsorship rclated data relating to subclass 457 visa grants. The data comes from a number of departmental receipting and processing systems. The key data relates to application receipting and processing, visa grants, client movement records and visa stock data. The sponsorship data includes company name and industry type and nominated occupation details. (4) The Business Visitor visa (subclass 456) is the only visitor visa that provides the holder with any form of work rights. The 456 visa is a shortstay visa (up to 3 months) which primarily provides for business people attending meetings and transacting business. It also provides for skilled specialists to work in situations where there is no adverse impact on employment and training opportunities for Australian citizens and permanent residents. An extract of visa stock data as at 31 March 1998 indicated there were 9,413 subclass 456 visa holders in Australia at that time. (5) In the calender year 1997 there were approximately 7,200 sponsorship approvals. Between 1 January and 30 April 1998 there were approximately 2,600 sponsorship approvals. Statistics relating to the numbers of refused business sponsorship are currently not available from Departmental systems. However, the Department's Business Centres advise that husiness sponsorship refusals are in the order of 5 to 10 per cent. (6) There is no readily available statistical data indicating industry categories associated with people changing to visa subclass 457 onshore. However, a table showing all approved nominations (on and olIshore) by industry groupings according to the Australian and New Zealand Standard Industrial Classification (ANZSIC) for 1 July 1997 to 30 April 1998 is attached.
